title: Wisdom and Folly
shortSummary: Proverbs 14 contrasts the wise and the foolish, highlighting the consequences of their choices in daily life and character. It emphasizes the fear of the Lord as the foundation of wisdom and the blessings of righteousness, while warning against pride, deceit, and wickedness.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Traditional period of Solomon's Proverbs composition

keyCharacters.name: Wise Woman
keyCharacters.description: Represents the prudent and godly woman who builds and sustains her household through wisdom and faithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Foolish Man
keyCharacters.description: Symbolizes those who reject wisdom, acting in pride and folly, leading to destruction and shame.

keyCharacters.name: Righteous Person
keyCharacters.description: One who fears the Lord and lives uprightly, receiving favor and hope even in death.

keyCharacters.name: Wicked Person
keyCharacters.description: One who oppresses others and lives in sin, ultimately facing downfall and reproach.

definitions.definition: A reverent awe and respect for God that leads to obedience and wisdom.
One who turns away from God and righteousness, returning to sinful ways.
A person who mocks or rejects wisdom and instruction, often leading to folly.
A metaphor for the harsh and destructive words or attitudes that come from a proud and foolish person.
A dwelling place or tent, here symbolizing the secure and flourishing home of the upright.

outline.heading: Wisdom and Folly in the Home and Speech
outline.description: This section contrasts the wise woman who builds her household with the foolish who destroys it, and highlights the power of uprightness, truthful speech, and the value of labor.

outline.heading: The Pursuit of Wisdom versus Folly
outline.description: Here the text contrasts those who seek and find wisdom with scorners and fools who reject it, emphasizing prudence, understanding, and the consequences of anger and folly.

outline.heading: Social and Moral Consequences
outline.description: This section discusses the social realities of wealth and poverty, the importance of mercy, the fear of the Lord as confidence and life, and the value of patience and a sound heart.

outline.heading: Righteousness and Wickedness in Society
outline.description: The chapter concludes by contrasting the honor of the righteous and the downfall of the wicked, highlighting the exaltation of righteousness and the king’s favor toward the wise.

application: Cultivate a reverent fear of the Lord as the foundation for wise living and confident trust in God’s protection.
Guard your speech and actions, seeking to build up others and avoid prideful or deceitful behavior that leads to destruction.
Practice mercy and kindness toward the poor and needy, reflecting God’s heart and receiving His blessing.
Be slow to anger and quick to seek understanding, demonstrating the wisdom that honors God and promotes peace.

keyVerses.text: Every wise woman buildeth her house: but the foolish plucketh it down with her hands.
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates the foundational role of wisdom in maintaining a godly and stable household.

keyVerses.text: There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning that human judgment apart from God can lead to destruction, underscoring the need for divine wisdom.

keyVerses.text: In the fear of the LORD is strong confidence: and his children shall have a place of refuge.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the protective power and assurance that come from reverence toward God.

keyVerses.text: Righteousness exalteth a nation: but sin is a reproach to any people.
keyVerses.significance: Shows the national impact of collective righteousness or sin, emphasizing the importance of godly living for society.
